White denotes regions with a centrist (Christian Democratic-Socialist) administration, Red denotes those with a leftist (Communist) administration. | image1 = [[Image:Luigi Ciriaco de Mita.jpg|100px]] | leader1 = [[Ciriaco De Mita]] | leader_since1 = [[1982]] | party1 = Christian Democracy (Italy)|DC | last_election1 = 290 seats, 40.3% | seats1 = 276 | swing1 = -14 | percentage1 = 38.3% | image2 = [[File:Alessandro Natta.jpg|113px]] | leader2 = [[Alessandro Natta]] | leader_since2 = [[1984]] | party2 = Italian Communist Party|PCI | last_election2 = 233 seats, 32.4% | seats2 = 225 | swing2 = -8 | percentage2 = 31.3% }} The '''Italian regional elections of 1985''' were held on [[May 12]]. The fifteen ordinary regions, created in 1970, elected their '''fourth''' assemblies. ==Electoral system== The pure [[party-list proportional representation]] had traditionally become the electoral system of [[Italy]], and it was adopted for the regional vote too. Each [[Italian province]] corresponded to a constituency electing a group of candidates. At constituency level, seats were divided between [[open list]]s using the [[largest remainder method]] with [[Droop quota]]. Remaining votes and seats were transferred at regional level, where they was divided using the [[Hare quota]], and automatically distributed to best losers into the local lists. ==Results== Summary of |[[Italian Socialist Party]] |17.9% |8 |[[File:Arrow-up.gif]] 1 |} The most relevant result of these elections was the switch of [[Piedmont]], which returned to the Christian Democracy after ten year of leftist administration. If the vote weakened both two major parties, the DC could compensate its loss with the reinforcement of its national allies, while the Communists became increasingly isolated, with [[Bettino Craxi|Craxi]]'s Socialists looking definitely at their right. Twelve Regional Councils elected a centrist administration, with the PSI rewarded by four presidencies, while the PCI was confined to its traditional strongholds: [[Emilia-Romagna|Emilia]], [[Tuscany]] and [[Umbria]]. The results strengthned Craxi's government after the alarming results of the 1984 European election, and they underlined the decline of the Communist party into a progressively post-industrial [[Italy]]. {{Elections in Italy}} [[Category:1985 elections in Italy]] [[Category:1985 in Italy|Regional elections]] [[Category:Elections in Italian regions]] [[ca:Eleccions regionals italianes de 1985]] [[it:Elezioni regionali italiane del 1985]]
